Calculating Protein Concentration

How do I make a standard curve in R?

Author
Brady Johnston
Published

April 1, 2022

A common experiment in any kind of lab is the creation of a standard curve to measure the concentration or amount of some unknown sample. Whether they be proteins, small molecules or anything in between, itâ€™s a standard lab procedure.

Code
# Protein Concentrations
prot <- c(0.000, 0.016, 0.031, 0.063, 0.125, 0.250, 0.500, 1.000, 
          0.000, 0.016, 0.031, 0.063, 0.125, 0.250, 0.500, 1.000) 

# Absorbance from my protein assay
abs <- c(0.329, 0.352, 0.349, 0.379, 0.417, 0.491, 0.668, 0.956, 
         0.327, 0.341, 0.355, 0.383, 0.417, 0.446, 0.655, 0.905)

data <- data.frame(
  prot = prot, 
  abs = abs
)

unknowns <- c(0.554, 0.568, 0.705)

head(data)
   prot   abs
1 0.000 0.329
2 0.016 0.352
3 0.031 0.349
4 0.063 0.379
5 0.125 0.417
6 0.250 0.491

The Easy Way

Using the package standard, we can fit a stanard curve and use it to predict what the concentrations are for our unkown proteins.

Fitting a Standard Curve

Code
#remotes::install_github("rforbiochemists/standard")
library(standard)

our_curve <- std_curve_fit(
  data = data, 
  conc = prot, 
  resp = abs
  )
plot(our_curve)

The \(R^{2}\) is good and we can confidently use this standard curve to predict what our unknown protein concentrations are.

Calculating our Unknowns

For this we can use the std_curve_predict() function, which takes a model output from std_curve_fit() and a vector of unknowns and returns the predicted values.

Code
std_curve_calc(
  std_curve = our_curve, 
  unknowns = unknowns
  ) %>% 
  knitr::kable()
abs prot
0.554 0.361
0.568 0.384
0.705 0.609

We can similarly just use plot() to quickly generate an informative plot with our standard curve and predicted values all plotted.

Code
std_curve_calc(
  std_curve = our_curve, 
  unknowns = unknowns
  ) %>% 
  plot()

What is {standard}?

Standard is an effort to make the use of R for calculating and applying standard curves in molecular biology as painless as possible.

Under the hood itâ€™s just fitting linear models, pulling out relevant statistics and using them to predict values. All of this may seem easy if you are exerienced in R - but the intention of this package is to create a beginner-friendly and reproducible API for doing common molecular biology tasks inside of R.

Fitting the Model

Code
mod <- lm(prot ~ abs, data = data)
summary(mod)

Call:
lm(formula = prot ~ abs, data = data)

Residuals:
      Min        1Q    Median        3Q       Max 
-0.048237 -0.013238 -0.008318  0.008180  0.067081 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) -0.55101    0.02031  -27.13 1.67e-13 ***
abs          1.64558    0.03878   42.43 3.42e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.03044 on 14 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.9923,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9917 
F-statistic:  1801 on 1 and 14 DF,  p-value: 3.421e-16

What about just the coefficients we are interested in?

Code
coefficients(mod)
(Intercept)         abs 
 -0.5510076   1.6455755

Which we can get in a bit nice format with the broom package.

Code
broom::tidy(mod)
# A tibble: 2 Ã— 5
  term        estimate std.error statistic  p.value
  <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>
1 (Intercept)   -0.551    0.0203     -27.1 1.67e-13
2 abs            1.65     0.0388      42.4 3.42e-16

The \(R^{2}\) can be extracted from the model using summary().

Code
r_squared <- summary(mod)$r.squared
print(r_squared)
[1] 0.9922846

With some unknowns, we can predict what the values will be. We must make sure that the column in this unkown data frame has the appropriate name, abs in this case which is the same as what we used in our original model.

We can use the base function predict() to get the predictions, or use the broom::augment() to get an already nicely formatted response.

Code
unk <- data.frame(
  abs = c(0.554, 0.568, 0.705)
)

predict(mod, unk)
        1         2         3 
0.3606412 0.3836793 0.6091231
Code
unk <- broom::augment(mod, newdata = unk)
Warning: 'newdata' had 3 rows but variables found have 16 rows
Code
unk
# A tibble: 3 Ã— 2
    abs .fitted
  <dbl>   <dbl>
1 0.554   0.361
2 0.568   0.384
3 0.705   0.609

To plot the results:

Code
library(ggplot2)
library(magrittr)
broom::augment(mod) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(prot, abs)) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", colour = "gray20", linetype = "dotted") + 
  geom_point(aes(y = abs), colour = "tomato", size = 4) + 
  geom_point(
    data = unk, 
    aes(x = .fitted, y = abs), 
    colour = "black", 
    alpha = 1,
    size = 6, 
    shape = 4
  ) + 
  theme_classic() + 
  theme(aspect.ratio = 0.5) + 
  labs(
    x = "[Protein] mg/mL", 
    y = "Absorbance (AU)"
  ) + 
  annotate(
    geom = "text", 
    x = 0.1, 
    y = 0.9, 
    label = paste("Rsq =", round(r_squared, 2))
  )
`geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'
